text: Solomon’s Praise of His Dancing Maiden
How beautiful are your feet in sandals,
O royal princess!\f + \fr 7:1 \ft Or “O daughter of leader” \f*
The curves of your ⸤thighs⸥\f + \fr 7:1 \ft Literally “thigh” \f* \add are\add* like ⸤jewels⸥,\f + \fr 7:1 \ft Literally “ornaments” \f*
the work of the hands of a craftsman.
Your navel \add is\add* ⸤a round wine-mixing bowl⸥\f + \fr 7:2 \ft Literally “a bowl of the roundness” \f*
that does not lack mixed\f + \fr 7:2 \ft Or “blended” \f* wine!
Your belly \add is\add* a heap of wheat
encircled with lilies.
Your two breasts \add are\add* like two fawns,
twins of a gazelle.
Your neck \add is\add* like a tower of ivory;
your eyes \add are\add* pools in Heshbon at the gate of Beth Rabbim.
Your nose \add is\add* like the tower of Lebanon
⸤looking out over Damascus⸥.\f + \fr 7:4 \ft Literally “looking out over the face of Damascus” \f*

⸤Your head crowns you like Carmel⸥;\f + \fr 7:5 \ft Literally “Your head \fq is \ft on you like the Carmel” \f*\f + \fr 7:5 \ft Because of its height and fertility, Mount Carmel is often associated with royalty \f*
the flowing locks of your head \add are\add* like ⸤purple tapestry⸥;\f + \fr 7:5 \ft Literally “the purple” \f*
a king is held captive in the tresses!
How beautiful you are and how pleasant,
O loved one in the delights!
⸤Your stature⸥\f + \fr 7:7 \ft Literally “this your height” \f* \add is\add* like the palm tree,
and your breasts \add are\add* like clusters.
I say, “I will climb up the palm tree;
I will lay hold of its fruit clusters.”
Let your breasts \add be pleasing\add* like clusters of the vine
and the scent of your breath like the apples.
Your palate \add is\add* like the best wine that goes down for my beloved,

smoothly gliding over my lips and teeth.\f + \fr 7:9 \ft Or “over lips of sleepers.” One Hebrew textual tradition preserves the reading “lips of those who sleep” (MT). Another Hebrew tradition reads “my lips and my teeth,” as reflected by the ancient versions (LXX, Latin Vulgate, Aramaic Targum, Syriac Peshitta). The latter is adopted here since it makes the most sense poetically \f*
Mutual Possession Refrain
⸤I belong to my beloved⸥,\f + \fr 7:10 \ft Literally “I \fq am \ft for my beloved” \f*
⸤and he desires me⸥!\f + \fr 7:10 \ft Literally “and his desire \fq is \ft for me.” Or “and his desire belongs to me” \f*
Rendezvous in the Countryside
Come, my beloved, let us ⸤go out to the countryside⸥;\f + \fr 7:11 \ft Literally “go forth into the field” \f*
let us spend the night\f + \fr 7:11 \ft Or “lodge” \f* in the villages.
Let us rise early \add to go\add*\f + \fr 7:12 \ft Or “let us go” \f* to the vineyards;
let us see whether the vine has budded,\f + \fr 7:12 \ft Or “sprouted” \f*
\add whether\add* the grape blossom has opened,
and \add whether\add* the pomegranates ⸤are in bloom⸥;\f + \fr 7:12 \ft Literally “have bloomed” \f*
there I will give my love to you.
The mandrakes give \add off their\add* fragrance,
and ⸤over our doorway is every kind of delicious fruit⸥;\f + \fr 7:13 \ft Or “over our doorways all choice \fq things \ft ” \f*
both ⸤fresh and dried fruit I have stored up⸥\f + \fr 7:13 \ft Literally “new also old I have laid up” \f* for you, O my beloved.
